This year, Debra Holbrook from Dalton High School Catamounts was named the first-ever recipient of the Dalton Education Foundation's Dale Cook Support Educator of the Year award.

The award was created by the family of Dale Cook and the Dalton Education Foundation as a way to recognize those support staff members who have made significant contributions for the educational opportunities of children in Dalton Public Schools. This award recognizes staff members who operate in behind-the-scenes roles that help the district run smoothly. A support staff member is defined as a non-certificated, non-classroom position at either the school or district level.

Read more on our website: https://www.daltonpublicschools.com/news/dalton-public-schools-news/~post/debra-holbrook-named-dale-cook-support-staff-member-of-the-year-20200831

The commitment and love she shows daily through her words and actions with everyone who walks in the school, and many other reasons makes her well deserved of the Dalton Difference coin." #IAmTheDaltonDifference

As this school year ends, we wanted to share information with you about summer school and how it will work this year. Right now, our plan is to offer summer school in much the same way that we have in the past. That has proved successful for our students recovering credits and graduating on time.

Rather than coming every day Mondays-Thursdays, students will sign up for 2 different shifts to attend. This is an effort to keep classrooms to 10 or fewer, while still serving everyone who needs summer school.

Registration for summer school will be done online through your Canvas Announcements. Click here for more information: https://www.daltonpublicschools.com/news/dalton-public-schools-news/~post/summer-school-registration-information-20200513

Thank you Mrs. Cooper for playing such an important role in our students lives, while teaching them they can be successful. You are the Dalton Difference!"

We're so proud of the Extended Digital Learning that started last week. This story comes to us from Andi White, a second grade teacher at Park Creek School - Serving, Learning, Leading:

"Yesterday, I scheduled a Zoom meeting with my class and I had 6 of my 17 who attended. They were bouncing all around and seemed so excited to see me and each other.

I read a book to them, asked them how they were doing, and talked to them about their Canvas work. I had 2 that didn’t want to use the video on the camera, so I didn’t force it. They could still see us and listen. I shared my screen with them demonstrating how to do different things and access the videos on Canvas that appear restricted.

Today, I received an email from one of my students asking for another zoom meeting."

We're proud of everyone for adapting quickly and working hard during this challenging time. Let's have another great week together! #DaltonDifference #DPSGoesVirtual 🐾💻

The College Board
March 16 at 2:26 PM ·

The College Board is developing tools to mitigate the impact of school closures on students in the Advanced Placement Program. All AP students and teachers will be able to draw on the free online resources that were provided to every AP classroom this fall. Additional resources will be made easily accessible to AP students and teachers through mobile phones and other devices. These include free online AP lessons and review sessions from some of the top AP teachers in the country.

The AP program is finalizing streamlined AP exam options that would allow students to test at home, depending on the situation in May. We’re working to give every AP student the opportunity to claim the credit they’ve earned. The AP Program will communicate the details of these additional solutions to educators and students by March 20.

The College Board’s focus will remain on student safety and ensuring all students have the tools they need to work, and opportunities to receive the credit they have earned, during this challenging time.

More details: http://spr.ly/61861srPq.

Marla Tucker at Blue Ridge School passed her Dalton Difference coin to Melanie Morgan! She said:

"As a school nurse since 1996, I have seen many patients. Some of my "frequent flyers" always came right before PE class. They would claim everything from polio (he read about it in a book!) to blindness (I almost believed her!) to get out of participation. It takes a one in a million teacher to motivate students to be their physical best self.

She must have rules to keep all of the activities safe, but still be fun and exciting. She goes out of her way to find equipment to teach lessons that will give students skills and knowledge that will keep them healthy for life. She adapts lessons to fit the abilities of all her students. She lives a lifestyle that promotes health and wellness everyday. She even co-ordinates activities for students on the weekend.

This year my patients come in and say, "Hurry up, I'm gonna miss PE!" Because Melanie Morgan is the Dalton Difference!"

I am so thankful I am able to work alongside her this year, and I can’t wait to see the wonderful things our students will make through her amazing support!"

German students at Brookwood Elementary arrived at school today to find their shoes filled with candy and goodies in celebration of Nikolaustag, or St. Nicholas Day.

Nikolaustag is celebrated in Germany each year. At night on December 5th, children clean and polish their shoes or boots and put them outside their front door in the hope that St. Nikolaus will pass by and fill them up with sweets. #DaltonDifference
